repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:
The cmdpreview saved undo nodes on `cmdpreview_prepare` from `ex_getln.c` may become invalid (free) if the preview function makes undo operations, causing heap-use-after-free errors.

Solution:
Save the buffer undo list on `cmdpreview_prepare` and start a new empty one. On `cmdpreview_restore_state`, undo all the entries in the new undo list and restore the original one. With this approach, the preview function will be allowed to undo only its own changes.

fix #20036
fix #20248

comment_data.body: What is the point of this change? It seems to make code more confusing.
The goal was to add a generic interface to save/restore the undo state.
The `save_*` prefix on each field seems redundant?

> The `save_*` prefix on each field seems redundant?

Agree. And if we remove the prefix, we could use it to replace the `b_u_*` loose fields from `file_buffer`.

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/ccf328172bac2b02f9bd19fa58e105958514a28a/src/nvim/buffer_defs.h#L568-L583

> > The `save_*` prefix on each field seems redundant?
> 
> Agree. And if we remove the prefix, we could use it to replace the `b_u_*` loose fields from `file_buffer`.
> 
> https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/ccf328172bac2b02f9bd19fa58e105958514a28a/src/nvim/buffer_defs.h#L568-L583

I like that idea a lot. Do you plan on making a PR for it?

I also thought these `b_u_` fields can moved into a struct with slightly different names, and then `#define`s can be added for the original names, but had some trouble giving a name to the struct and its fields.

comment_regular_data.body: Perhaps it would be a good idea to move the undo related save/restore to their own functions that get called within the cmdpreview prepare/restore functions, to clean up `cmdpreview_prepare()` and `cmdpreview_restore_state()`
I'm not sure if not saving and restoring `b_u_save_nr_cur` and `b_u_save_nr_last` could potentially cause problems, but that might be the case and is worth looking into

> Perhaps it would be a good idea to move the undo related save/restore to their own functions that get called within the cmdpreview prepare/restore functions, to clean up `cmdpreview_prepare()` and `cmdpreview_restore_state()`

> I'm not sure if not saving and restoring `b_u_save_nr_cur` and `b_u_save_nr_last` could potentially cause problems, but that might be the case and is worth looking into

I've unified the undo state restoration from cmd preview callback and `undofile` to remove duplicate code. As both `b_u_save_nr_cur` and `b_u_save_nr_last` were restored by `undofile`, I've included them in the undo state save/restore functions.

> I'm not sure if not saving and restoring `b_u_save_nr_cur` and `b_u_save_nr_last` could potentially cause problems, but that might be the case and is worth looking into

I guess not saving these fields could be a problem if the preview callback function make calls to `vim.cmd.write()`, but that can cause other weird behaviors. For example, the user command below will write a modified version of the buffer and this won't be undone when it leaves the preview callback.

```lua
vim.api.nvim_create_user_command('Foo', function() end, {
  nargs = '?',
  preview = function()
    vim.cmd('norm ifoo')
    vim.cmd.write()
  end,
})
```

title: fix(inccommand): restrict cmdpreview undo calls
